section.title: Introduction to Periodic Functions
section.p: A function is called periodic if it repeats itself regularly. In this section, we will explore the basics of periodic functions by considering real-world examples.

statement.p: The following graph shows the % battery charge on a cell phone as a function of the number of hours after midnight.

li.p: How many hours does it take to charge the phone?
What time does the user begin recharging the phone each day?
This function is periodic, meaning that it repeats itself over and over.
How many hours does it take to repeat itself completely?
It takes 6 hours to fully rechage the phone.
The user begins recharging the phone at 6:00 P.M. each day.
It takes 24 hours for this function to repeat itself.

section.p: In the last exercise, the function repeated itself every 24 hours. This is called the period of the function the smallest value of the input, after which the function repeats itself again. It is also true that the function repeats itself every 48 hours, but this isn't the smallest number for which it repeats. The period is defined as the smallest such number.
The next exercise will become the fundamental example of a periodic function in this course. It involves a person riding a Ferris Wheel.

At bottom left is a diagram of the Ferris Wheel. Using the sliders at right, you can adjust things like the wheel's radius, the height of the loading platform, or the period of the wheel.

li.p: To start, the Ferris wheel has a radius of 10 meters, passengers board it from the ground (a height of 0 meters), and it takes 10 minutes to complete a rotation.

Use the bottom slider to increase the time, and two things will happen:
The passenger (shown by a red triangle) will move around the Ferris Wheel.
the passenger's height above the ground will be graphed as a function of time.
Next, use the slider to change the radius to 30 meters. Move the time slider and notice the change made to the graph.
Next, use the slider to move the height of the boarding platform. Move the time slider and notice the change made to the graph.
Finally, use the slider to change the period of the Ferris Wheel so it completes a revolution every 20 minutes. Move the time slider and notice the change made to the graph.

statement.p: If the function is called f(t) when the period is 10 minutes, then changing the period to 30 minutes brings about a horizontal stretch to the graph.
Changing the period to 30 minutes is which transformation?

section.p: In the Ferris Wheel problem, there are a few other things to notice.
First, the height of the person as they go around the circle has nice symmetry the graph on the way up is a reflection of the graph on the way down.

Next, the graph oscillates up and down around a middle height. For periodic functions, this height is called the midline. For example, when the radius was 20 meters and the loading platform was 10 meters, the midline was the height y = 30 meters.
In fact, the midline is usually given in equation form, such as: y = b
Finally, the radius of the wheel is easily seen on the graph, as the distance between the midline and either the highest point, or the lowest point.
Because not every periodic function involves movement around a circle, we give this distance a more general term: The Amplitude
In general, the amplitude of a periodic function is the difference (along the output axis) between the maximum output and midline (or between the midline and the minimum output).
